IM_MSVC_RUNTIME_CHECKS_RESTORE
1901
1902
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1903
// [SECTION] ImGuiStyle
1904
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1905
// You may modify the ImGui::GetStyle() main instance during initialization and before NewFrame().
1906
// During the frame, use ImGui::PushStyleVar(ImGuiStyleVar_XXXX)/PopStyleVar() to alter the main style values,
1907
// and ImGui::PushStyleColor(ImGuiCol_XXX)/PopStyleColor() for colors.
1908
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1909
1910
struct ImGuiStyle
1911
{
1912
    float       Alpha;                      // Global alpha applies to everything in Dear ImGui.
1913
    float       DisabledAlpha;              // Additional alpha multiplier applied by BeginDisabled(). Multiply over current value of Alpha.
1914
    ImVec2      WindowPadding;              // Padding within a window.
1915
    float       WindowRounding;             // Radius of window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows. Large values tend to lead to variety of artifacts and are not recommended.
1916
    float       WindowBorderSize;           // Thickness of border around windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1917
    ImVec2      WindowMinSize;              // Minimum window size. This is a global setting. If you want to constrain individual windows, use SetNextWindowSizeConstraints().
1918
    ImVec2      WindowTitleAlign;           // Alignment for title bar text. Defaults to (0.0f,0.5f) for left-aligned,vertically centered.
1919
    ImGuiDir    WindowMenuButtonPosition;   // Side of the collapsing/docking button in the title bar (None/Left/Right). Defaults to ImGuiDir_Left.
1920
    float       ChildRounding;              // Radius of child window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows.
1921
    float       ChildBorderSize;            // Thickness of border around child windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1922
    float       PopupRounding;              // Radius of popup window corners rounding. (Note that tooltip windows use WindowRounding)
1923
    float       PopupBorderSize;            // Thickness of border around popup/tooltip windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1924
    ImVec2      FramePadding;               // Padding within a framed rectangle (used by most widgets).
1925
    float       FrameRounding;              // Radius of frame corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular frame (used by most widgets).
1926
    float       FrameBorderSize;            // Thickness of border around frames. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1927
    ImVec2      ItemSpacing;                // Horizontal and vertical spacing between widgets/lines.
1928
    ImVec2      ItemInnerSpacing;           // Horizontal and vertical spacing between within elements of a composed widget (e.g. a slider and its label).
1929
    ImVec2      CellPadding;                // Padding within a table cell
1930
    ImVec2      TouchExtraPadding;          // Expand reactive bounding box for touch-based system where touch position is not accurate enough. Unfortunately we don't sort widgets so priority on overlap will always be given to the first widget. So don't grow this too much!
1931
    float       IndentSpacing;              // Horizontal indentation when e.g. entering a tree node. Generally == (FontSize + FramePadding.x*2).
1932
    float       ColumnsMinSpacing;          // Minimum horizontal spacing between two columns. Preferably > (FramePadding.x + 1).
1933
    float       ScrollbarSize;              // Width of the vertical scrollbar, Height of the horizontal scrollbar.
1934
    float       ScrollbarRounding;          // Radius of grab corners for scrollbar.
1935
    float       GrabMinSize;                // Minimum width/height of a grab box for slider/scrollbar.
1936
    float       GrabRounding;               // Radius of grabs corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular slider grabs.
1937
    float       LogSliderDeadzone;          // The size in pixels of the dead-zone around zero on logarithmic sliders that cross zero.
1938
    float       TabRounding;                // Radius of upper corners of a tab. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular tabs.
1939
    float       TabBorderSize;              // Thickness of border around tabs.
1940
    float       TabMinWidthForCloseButton;  // Minimum width for close button to appear on an unselected tab when hovered. Set to 0.0f to always show when hovering, set to FLT_MAX to never show close button unless selected.
1941
    ImGuiDir    ColorButtonPosition;        // Side of the color button in the ColorEdit4 widget (left/right). Defaults to ImGuiDir_Right.
1942
    ImVec2      ButtonTextAlign;            // Alignment of button text when button is larger than text. Defaults to (0.5f, 0.5f) (centered).
1943
    ImVec2      SelectableTextAlign;        // Alignment of selectable text. Defaults to (0.0f, 0.0f) (top-left aligned). It's generally important to keep this left-aligned if you want to lay multiple items on a same line.
1944
    float       SeparatorTextBorderSize;    // Thickkness of border in SeparatorText()
1945
    ImVec2      SeparatorTextAlign;         // Alignment of text within the separator. Defaults to (0.0f, 0.5f) (left aligned, center).
1946
    ImVec2      SeparatorTextPadding;       // Horizontal offset of text from each edge of the separator + spacing on other axis. Generally small values. .y is recommended to be == FramePadding.y.
1947
    ImVec2      DisplayWindowPadding;       // Window position are clamped to be visible within the display area or monitors by at least this amount. Only applies to regular windows.
1948
    ImVec2      DisplaySafeAreaPadding;     // If you cannot see the edges of your screen (e.g. on a TV) increase the safe area padding. Apply to popups/tooltips as well regular windows. NB: Prefer configuring your TV sets correctly!
1949
    float       MouseCursorScale;           // Scale software rendered mouse cursor (when io.MouseDrawCursor is enabled). We apply per-monitor DPI scaling over this scale. May be removed later.
1950
    bool        AntiAliasedLines;           // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders. Disable if you are really tight on CPU/GPU. Latched at the beginning of the frame (copied to ImDrawList).
1951
    bool        AntiAliasedLinesUseTex;     // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders using textures where possible. Require backend to render with bilinear filtering (NOT point/nearest filtering). Latched at the beginning of the frame (copied to ImDrawList).
1952
    bool        AntiAliasedFill;            // Enable anti-aliased edges around filled shapes (rounded rectangles, circles, etc.). Disable if you are really tight on CPU/GPU. Latched at the beginning of the frame (copied to ImDrawList).
1953
    float       CurveTessellationTol;       // Tessellation tolerance when using PathBezierCurveTo() without a specific number of segments. Decrease for highly tessellated curves (higher quality, more polygons), increase to reduce quality.
1954
    float       CircleTessellationMaxError; // Maximum error (in pixels) allowed when using AddCircle()/AddCircleFilled() or drawing rounded corner rectangles with no explicit segment count specified. Decrease for higher quality but more geometry.
1955
    ImVec4      Colors[ImGuiCol_COUNT];
1956
1957
    IMGUI_API ImGuiStyle();
1958
    IMGUI_API void ScaleAllSizes(float scale_factor);
1959
};
1960
1961
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1962
// [SECTION] ImGuiIO
1963
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1964
// Communicate most settings and inputs/outputs to Dear ImGui using this structure.
1965
// Access via ImGui::GetIO(). Read 'Programmer guide' section in .cpp file for general usage.
1966
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1967
1968
// [Internal] Storage used by IsKeyDown(), IsKeyPressed() etc functions.
1969
// If prior to 1.87 you used io.KeysDownDuration[] (which was marked as internal), you should use GetKeyData(key)->DownDuration and *NOT* io.KeysData[key]->DownDuration.
1970
struct ImGuiKeyData
1971
{
1972
    bool        Down;               // True for if key is down
1973
    float       DownDuration;       // Duration the key has been down (<0.0f: not pressed, 0.0f: just pressed, >0.0f: time held)
1974
    float       DownDurationPrev;   // Last frame duration the key has been down
1975
    float       AnalogValue;        // 0.0f..1.0f for gamepad values
1976
};
1977
1978
struct ImGuiIO
1979
{
1980
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
1981
    // Configuration                            // Default value
1982
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
1983
1984
    ImGuiConfigFlags   ConfigFlags;             // = 0              // See ImGuiConfigFlags_ enum. Set by user/application. Gamepad/keyboard navigation options, etc.
1985
    ImGuiBackendFlags  BackendFlags;            // = 0              // See ImGuiBackendFlags_ enum. Set by backend (imgui_impl_xxx files or custom backend) to communicate features supported by the backend.
1986
    ImVec2      DisplaySize;                    // <unset>          // Main display size, in pixels (generally == GetMainViewport()->Size). May change every frame.
1987
    float       DeltaTime;                      // = 1.0f/60.0f     // Time elapsed since last frame, in seconds. May change every frame.
1988
    float       IniSavingRate;                  // = 5.0f           // Minimum time between saving positions/sizes to .ini file, in seconds.
1989
    const char* IniFilename;                    // = "imgui.ini"    // Path to .ini file (important: default "imgui.ini" is relative to current working dir!). Set NULL to disable automatic .ini loading/saving or if you want to manually call LoadIniSettingsXXX() / SaveIniSettingsXXX() functions.
1990
    const char* LogFilename;                    // = "imgui_log.txt"// Path to .log file (default parameter to ImGui::LogToFile when no file is specified).
1991
    float       MouseDoubleClickTime;           // = 0.30f          // Time for a double-click, in seconds.
1992
    float       MouseDoubleClickMaxDist;        // = 6.0f           // Distance threshold to stay in to validate a double-click, in pixels.
1993
    float       MouseDragThreshold;             // = 6.0f           // Distance threshold before considering we are dragging.
1994
    float       KeyRepeatDelay;                 // = 0.275f         // When holding a key/button, time before it starts repeating, in seconds (for buttons in Repeat mode, etc.).
1995
    float       KeyRepeatRate;                  // = 0.050f         // When holding a key/button, rate at which it repeats, in seconds.
1996
    float       HoverDelayNormal;               // = 0.30 sec       // Delay on hovering before IsItemHovered(ImGuiHoveredFlags_DelayNormal) returns true.
1997
    float       HoverDelayShort;                // = 0.10 sec       // Delay on hovering before IsItemHovered(ImGuiHoveredFlags_DelayShort) returns true.
1998
    void*       UserData;                       // = NULL           // Store your own data.
1999
2000
    ImFontAtlas*Fonts;                          // <auto>           // Font atlas: load, rasterize and pack one or more fonts into a single texture.
2001
    float       FontGlobalScale;                // = 1.0f           // Global scale all fonts
2002
    bool        FontAllowUserScaling;           // = false          // Allow user scaling text of individual window with CTRL+Wheel.
2003
    ImFont*     FontDefault;                    // = NULL           // Font to use on NewFrame(). Use NULL to uses Fonts->Fonts[0].
2004
    ImVec2      DisplayFramebufferScale;        // = (1, 1)         // For retina display or other situations where window coordinates are different from framebuffer coordinates. This generally ends up in ImDrawData::FramebufferScale.
2005
2006
    // Docking options (when ImGuiConfigFlags_DockingEnable is set)
2007
    bool        ConfigDockingNoSplit;           // = false          // Simplified docking mode: disable window splitting, so docking is limited to merging multiple windows together into tab-bars.
2008
    bool        ConfigDockingWithShift;         // = false          // Enable docking with holding Shift key (reduce visual noise, allows dropping in wider space)
2009
    bool        ConfigDockingAlwaysTabBar;      // = false          // [BETA] [FIXME: This currently creates regression with auto-sizing and general overhead] Make every single floating window display within a docking node.
2010
    bool        ConfigDockingTransparentPayload;// = false          // [BETA] Make window or viewport transparent when docking and only display docking boxes on the target viewport. Useful if rendering of multiple viewport cannot be synced. Best used with ConfigViewportsNoAutoMerge.
2011
2012
    // Viewport options (when ImGuiConfigFlags_ViewportsEnable is set)
2013
    bool        ConfigViewportsNoAutoMerge;     // = false;         // Set to make all floating imgui windows always create their own viewport. Otherwise, they are merged into the main host viewports when overlapping it. May also set ImGuiViewportFlags_NoAutoMerge on individual viewport.
2014
    bool        ConfigViewportsNoTaskBarIcon;   // = false          // Disable default OS task bar icon flag for secondary viewports. When a viewport doesn't want a task bar icon, ImGuiViewportFlags_NoTaskBarIcon will be set on it.
2015
    bool        ConfigViewportsNoDecoration;    // = true           // Disable default OS window decoration flag for secondary viewports. When a viewport doesn't want window decorations, ImGuiViewportFlags_NoDecoration will be set on it. Enabling decoration can create subsequent issues at OS levels (e.g. minimum window size).
2016
    bool        ConfigViewportsNoDefaultParent; // = false          // Disable default OS parenting to main viewport for secondary viewports. By default, viewports are marked with ParentViewportId = <main_viewport>, expecting the platform backend to setup a parent/child relationship between the OS windows (some backend may ignore this). Set to true if you want the default to be 0, then all viewports will be top-level OS windows.
2017
2018
    // Miscellaneous options
2019
    bool        MouseDrawCursor;                // = false          // Request ImGui to draw a mouse cursor for you (if you are on a platform without a mouse cursor). Cannot be easily renamed to 'io.ConfigXXX' because this is frequently used by backend implementations.
2020
    bool        ConfigMacOSXBehaviors;          // = defined(__APPLE__) // OS X style: Text editing cursor movement using Alt instead of Ctrl, Shortcuts using Cmd/Super instead of Ctrl, Line/Text Start and End using Cmd+Arrows instead of Home/End, Double click selects by word instead of selecting whole text, Multi-selection in lists uses Cmd/Super instead of Ctrl.
2021
    bool        ConfigInputTrickleEventQueue;   // = true           // Enable input queue trickling: some types of events submitted during the same frame (e.g. button down + up) will be spread over multiple frames, improving interactions with low framerates.
2022
    bool        ConfigInputTextCursorBlink;     // = true           // Enable blinking cursor (optional as some users consider it to be distracting).
2023
    bool        ConfigInputTextEnterKeepActive; // = false          // [BETA] Pressing Enter will keep item active and select contents (single-line only).
2024
    bool        ConfigDragClickToInputText;     // = false          // [BETA] Enable turning DragXXX widgets into text input with a simple mouse click-release (without moving). Not desirable on devices without a keyboard.
2025
    bool        ConfigWindowsResizeFromEdges;   // = true           // Enable resizing of windows from their edges and from the lower-left corner. This requires (io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseCursors) because it needs mouse cursor feedback. (This used to be a per-window ImGuiWindowFlags_ResizeFromAnySide flag)
2026
    bool        ConfigWindowsMoveFromTitleBarOnly; // = false       // Enable allowing to move windows only when clicking on their title bar. Does not apply to windows without a title bar.
2027
    float       ConfigMemoryCompactTimer;       // = 60.0f          // Timer (in seconds) to free transient windows/tables memory buffers when unused. Set to -1.0f to disable.
2028
2029
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2030
    // Platform Functions
2031
    // (the imgui_impl_xxxx backend files are setting those up for you)
2032
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2033
2034
    // Optional: Platform/Renderer backend name (informational only! will be displayed in About Window) + User data for backend/wrappers to store their own stuff.
2035
    const char* BackendPlatformName;            // = NULL
2036
    const char* BackendRendererName;            // = NULL
2037
    void*       BackendPlatformUserData;        // = NULL           // User data for platform backend
2038
    void*       BackendRendererUserData;        // = NULL           // User data for renderer backend
2039
    void*       BackendLanguageUserData;        // = NULL           // User data for non C++ programming language backend
2040
2041
    // Optional: Access OS clipboard
2042
    // (default to use native Win32 clipboard on Windows, otherwise uses a private clipboard. Override to access OS clipboard on other architectures)
2043
    const char* (*GetClipboardTextFn)(void* user_data);
2044
    void        (*SetClipboardTextFn)(void* user_data, const char* text);
2045
    void*       ClipboardUserData;
2046
2047
    // Optional: Notify OS Input Method Editor of the screen position of your cursor for text input position (e.g. when using Japanese/Chinese IME on Windows)
2048
    // (default to use native imm32 api on Windows)
2049
    void        (*SetPlatformImeDataFn)(ImGuiViewport* viewport, ImGuiPlatformImeData* data);
2050
#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
2051
    void*       ImeWindowHandle;                // = NULL           // [Obsolete] Set ImGuiViewport::PlatformHandleRaw instead. Set this to your HWND to get automatic IME cursor positioning.
2052
#else
2053
    void*       _UnusedPadding;                                     // Unused field to keep data structure the same size.
2054
#endif
2055
2056
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2057
    // Input - Call before calling NewFrame()
2058
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2059
2060
    // Input Functions
2061
    IMGUI_API void  AddKeyEvent(ImGuiKey key, bool down);                   // Queue a new key down/up event. Key should be "translated" (as in, generally ImGuiKey_A matches the key end-user would use to emit an 'A' character)
2062
    IMGUI_API void  AddKeyAnalogEvent(ImGuiKey key, bool down, float v);    // Queue a new key down/up event for analog values (e.g. ImGuiKey_Gamepad_ values). Dead-zones should be handled by the backend.
2063
    IMGUI_API void  AddMousePosEvent(float x, float y);                     // Queue a mouse position update. Use -FLT_MAX,-FLT_MAX to signify no mouse (e.g. app not focused and not hovered)
2064
    IMGUI_API void  AddMouseButtonEvent(int button, bool down);             // Queue a mouse button change
2065
    IMGUI_API void  AddMouseWheelEvent(float wheel_x, float wheel_y);       // Queue a mouse wheel update. wheel_y<0: scroll down, wheel_y>0: scroll up, wheel_x<0: scroll right, wheel_x>0: scroll left.
2066
    IMGUI_API void  AddMouseViewportEvent(ImGuiID id);                      // Queue a mouse hovered viewport. Requires backend to set ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseHoveredViewport to call this (for multi-viewport support).
2067
    IMGUI_API void  AddFocusEvent(bool focused);                            // Queue a gain/loss of focus for the application (generally based on OS/platform focus of your window)
2068
    IMGUI_API void  AddInputCharacter(unsigned int c);                      // Queue a new character input
2069
    IMGUI_API void  AddInputCharacterUTF16(ImWchar16 c);                    // Queue a new character input from a UTF-16 character, it can be a surrogate
2070
    IMGUI_API void  AddInputCharactersUTF8(const char* str);                // Queue a new characters input from a UTF-8 string
2071
2072
    IMGUI_API void  SetKeyEventNativeData(ImGuiKey key, int native_keycode, int native_scancode, int native_legacy_index = -1); // [Optional] Specify index for legacy <1.87 IsKeyXXX() functions with native indices + specify native keycode, scancode.
2073
    IMGUI_API void  SetAppAcceptingEvents(bool accepting_events);           // Set master flag for accepting key/mouse/text events (default to true). Useful if you have native dialog boxes that are interrupting your application loop/refresh, and you want to disable events being queued while your app is frozen.
2074
    IMGUI_API void  ClearInputCharacters();                                 // [Internal] Clear the text input buffer manually
2075
    IMGUI_API void  ClearInputKeys();                                       // [Internal] Release all keys
2076
2077
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2078
    // Output - Updated by NewFrame() or EndFrame()/Render()
2079
    // (when reading from the io.WantCaptureMouse, io.WantCaptureKeyboard flags to dispatch your inputs, it is
2080
    //  generally easier and more correct to use their state BEFORE calling NewFrame(). See FAQ for details!)
2081
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2082
2083
    bool        WantCaptureMouse;                   // Set when Dear ImGui will use mouse inputs, in this case do not dispatch them to your main game/application (either way, always pass on mouse inputs to imgui). (e.g. unclicked mouse is hovering over an imgui window, widget is active, mouse was clicked over an imgui window, etc.).
2084
    bool        WantCaptureKeyboard;                // Set when Dear ImGui will use keyboard inputs, in this case do not dispatch them to your main game/application (either way, always pass keyboard inputs to imgui). (e.g. InputText active, or an imgui window is focused and navigation is enabled, etc.).
2085
    bool        WantTextInput;                      // Mobile/console: when set, you may display an on-screen keyboard. This is set by Dear ImGui when it wants textual keyboard input to happen (e.g. when a InputText widget is active).
2086
    bool        WantSetMousePos;                    // MousePos has been altered, backend should reposition mouse on next frame. Rarely used! Set only when ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableSetMousePos flag is enabled.
2087
    bool        WantSaveIniSettings;                // When manual .ini load/save is active (io.IniFilename == NULL), this will be set to notify your application that you can call SaveIniSettingsToMemory() and save yourself. Important: clear io.WantSaveIniSettings yourself after saving!
2088
    bool        NavActive;                          // Keyboard/Gamepad navigation is currently allowed (will handle ImGuiKey_NavXXX events) = a window is focused and it doesn't use the ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs flag.
2089
    bool        NavVisible;                         // Keyboard/Gamepad navigation is visible and allowed (will handle ImGuiKey_NavXXX events).
2090
    float       Framerate;                          // Estimate of application framerate (rolling average over 60 frames, based on io.DeltaTime), in frame per second. Solely for convenience. Slow applications may not want to use a moving average or may want to reset underlying buffers occasionally.
2091
    int         MetricsRenderVertices;              // Vertices output during last call to Render()
2092
    int         MetricsRenderIndices;               // Indices output during last call to Render() = number of triangles * 3
2093
    int         MetricsRenderWindows;               // Number of visible windows
2094
    int         MetricsActiveWindows;               // Number of active windows
2095
    int         MetricsActiveAllocations;           // Number of active allocations, updated by MemAlloc/MemFree based on current context. May be off if you have multiple imgui contexts.
2096
    ImVec2      MouseDelta;                         // Mouse delta. Note that this is zero if either current or previous position are invalid (-FLT_MAX,-FLT_MAX), so a disappearing/reappearing mouse won't have a huge delta.
2097
2098
    // Legacy: before 1.87, we required backend to fill io.KeyMap[] (imgui->native map) during initialization and io.KeysDown[] (native indices) every frame.
2099
    // This is still temporarily supported as a legacy feature. However the new preferred scheme is for backend to call io.AddKeyEvent().
2100
    //   Old (<1.87):  ImGui::IsKeyPressed(ImGui::GetIO().KeyMap[ImGuiKey_Space]) --> New (1.87+) ImGui::IsKeyPressed(ImGuiKey_Space)
2101
#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_KEYIO
2102
    int         KeyMap[ImGuiKey_COUNT];             // [LEGACY] Input: map of indices into the KeysDown[512] entries array which represent your "native" keyboard state. The first 512 are now unused and should be kept zero. Legacy backend will write into KeyMap[] using ImGuiKey_ indices which are always >512.
2103
    bool        KeysDown[ImGuiKey_COUNT];           // [LEGACY] Input: Keyboard keys that are pressed (ideally left in the "native" order your engine has access to keyboard keys, so you can use your own defines/enums for keys). This used to be [512] sized. It is now ImGuiKey_COUNT to allow legacy io.KeysDown[GetKeyIndex(...)] to work without an overflow.
2104
    float       NavInputs[ImGuiNavInput_COUNT];     // [LEGACY] Since 1.88, NavInputs[] was removed. Backends from 1.60 to 1.86 won't build. Feed gamepad inputs via io.AddKeyEvent() and ImGuiKey_GamepadXXX enums.
2105
#endif
2106
2107
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2108
    // [Internal] Dear ImGui will maintain those fields. Forward compatibility not guaranteed!
2109
    //------------------------------------------------------------------
2110
2111
    // Main Input State
2112
    // (this block used to be written by backend, since 1.87 it is best to NOT write to those directly, call the AddXXX functions above instead)
2113
    // (reading from those variables is fair game, as they are extremely unlikely to be moving anywhere)
2114
    ImVec2      MousePos;                           // Mouse position, in pixels. Set to ImVec2(-FLT_MAX, -FLT_MAX) if mouse is unavailable (on another screen, etc.)
2115
    bool        MouseDown[5];                       // Mouse buttons: 0=left, 1=right, 2=middle + extras (ImGuiMouseButton_COUNT == 5). Dear ImGui mostly uses left and right buttons. Other buttons allow us to track if the mouse is being used by your application + available to user as a convenience via IsMouse** API.
2116
    float       MouseWheel;                         // Mouse wheel Vertical: 1 unit scrolls about 5 lines text. >0 scrolls Up, <0 scrolls Down. Hold SHIFT to turn vertical scroll into horizontal scroll.
2117
    float       MouseWheelH;                        // Mouse wheel Horizontal. >0 scrolls Left, <0 scrolls Right. Most users don't have a mouse with a horizontal wheel, may not be filled by all backends.
2118
    ImGuiID     MouseHoveredViewport;               // (Optional) Modify using io.AddMouseViewportEvent(). With multi-viewports: viewport the OS mouse is hovering. If possible _IGNORING_ viewports with the ImGuiViewportFlags_NoInputs flag is much better (few backends can handle that). Set io.BackendFlags |= ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseHoveredViewport if you can provide this info. If you don't imgui will infer the value using the rectangles and last focused time of the viewports it knows about (ignoring other OS windows).
2119
    bool        KeyCtrl;                            // Keyboard modifier down: Control
2120
    bool        KeyShift;                           // Keyboard modifier down: Shift
2121
    bool        KeyAlt;                             // Keyboard modifier down: Alt
2122
    bool        KeySuper;                           // Keyboard modifier down: Cmd/Super/Windows
2123
2124
    // Other state maintained from data above + IO function calls
2125
    ImGuiKeyChord KeyMods;                          // Key mods flags (any of ImGuiMod_Ctrl/ImGuiMod_Shift/ImGuiMod_Alt/ImGuiMod_Super flags, same as io.KeyCtrl/KeyShift/KeyAlt/KeySuper but merged into flags. DOES NOT CONTAINS ImGuiMod_Shortcut which is pretranslated). Read-only, updated by NewFrame()
2126
    ImGuiKeyData  KeysData[ImGuiKey_KeysData_SIZE]; // Key state for all known keys. Use IsKeyXXX() functions to access this.
2127
    bool        WantCaptureMouseUnlessPopupClose;   // Alternative to WantCaptureMouse: (WantCaptureMouse == true && WantCaptureMouseUnlessPopupClose == false) when a click over void is expected to close a popup.
2128
    ImVec2      MousePosPrev;                       // Previous mouse position (note that MouseDelta is not necessary == MousePos-MousePosPrev, in case either position is invalid)
2129
    ImVec2      MouseClickedPos[5];                 // Position at time of clicking
2130
    double      MouseClickedTime[5];                // Time of last click (used to figure out double-click)
2131
    bool        MouseClicked[5];                    // Mouse button went from !Down to Down (same as MouseClickedCount[x] != 0)
2132
    bool        MouseDoubleClicked[5];              // Has mouse button been double-clicked? (same as MouseClickedCount[x] == 2)
2133
    ImU16       MouseClickedCount[5];               // == 0 (not clicked), == 1 (same as MouseClicked[]), == 2 (double-clicked), == 3 (triple-clicked) etc. when going from !Down to Down
2134
    ImU16       MouseClickedLastCount[5];           // Count successive number of clicks. Stays valid after mouse release. Reset after another click is done.
2135
    bool        MouseReleased[5];                   // Mouse button went from Down to !Down
2136
    bool        MouseDownOwned[5];                  // Track if button was clicked inside a dear imgui window or over void blocked by a popup. We don't request mouse capture from the application if click started outside ImGui bounds.
2137
    bool        MouseDownOwnedUnlessPopupClose[5];  // Track if button was clicked inside a dear imgui window.
2138
    float       MouseDownDuration[5];               // Duration the mouse button has been down (0.0f == just clicked)
2139
    float       MouseDownDurationPrev[5];           // Previous time the mouse button has been down
2140
    ImVec2      MouseDragMaxDistanceAbs[5];         // Maximum distance, absolute, on each axis, of how much mouse has traveled from the clicking point
2141
    float       MouseDragMaxDistanceSqr[5];         // Squared maximum distance of how much mouse has traveled from the clicking point (used for moving thresholds)
2142
    float       PenPressure;                        // Touch/Pen pressure (0.0f to 1.0f, should be >0.0f only when MouseDown[0] == true). Helper storage currently unused by Dear ImGui.
2143
    bool        AppFocusLost;                       // Only modify via AddFocusEvent()
2144
    bool        AppAcceptingEvents;                 // Only modify via SetAppAcceptingEvents()
2145
    ImS8        BackendUsingLegacyKeyArrays;        // -1: unknown, 0: using AddKeyEvent(), 1: using legacy io.KeysDown[]
2146
    bool        BackendUsingLegacyNavInputArray;    // 0: using AddKeyAnalogEvent(), 1: writing to legacy io.NavInputs[] directly
2147
    ImWchar16   InputQueueSurrogate;                // For AddInputCharacterUTF16()
2148
    ImVector<ImWchar> InputQueueCharacters;         // Queue of _characters_ input (obtained by platform backend). Fill using AddInputCharacter() helper.
2149
2150
    IMGUI_API   ImGuiIO();
2151
};
2152
2153
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2154
// [SECTION] Misc data structures
2155
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2156
2157
// Shared state of InputText(), passed as an argument to your callback when a ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* flag is used.
2158
// The callback function should return 0 by default.
2159
// Callbacks (follow a flag name and see comments in ImGuiInputTextFlags_ declarations for more details)
2160
// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackEdit:        Callback on buffer edit (note that InputText() already returns true on edit, the callback is useful mainly to manipulate the underlying buffer while focus is active)
2161
// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackAlways:      Callback on each iteration
2162
// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCompletion:  Callback on pressing TAB
2163
// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackHistory:     Callback on pressing Up/Down arrows
2164
// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCharFilter:  Callback on character inputs to replace or discard them. Modify 'EventChar' to replace or discard, or return 1 in callback to discard.
2165
// - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackResize:      Callback on buffer capacity changes request (beyond 'buf_size' parameter value), allowing the string to grow.
2166
struct ImGuiInputTextCallbackData
2167
{
2168
    ImGuiInputTextFlags EventFlag;      // One ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback*    // Read-only
2169
    ImGuiInputTextFlags Flags;          // What user passed to InputText()      // Read-only
2170
    void*               UserData;       // What user passed to InputText()      // Read-only
2171
2172
    // Arguments for the different callback events
2173
    // - To modify the text buffer in a callback, prefer using the InsertChars() / DeleteChars() function. InsertChars() will take care of calling the resize callback if necessary.
2174
    // - If you know your edits are not going to resize the underlying buffer allocation, you may modify the contents of 'Buf[]' directly. You need to update 'BufTextLen' accordingly (0 <= BufTextLen < BufSize) and set 'BufDirty'' to true so InputText can update its internal state.
2175
    ImWchar             EventChar;      // Character input                      // Read-write   // [CharFilter] Replace character with another one, or set to zero to drop. return 1 is equivalent to setting EventChar=0;
2176
    ImGuiKey            EventKey;       // Key pressed (Up/Down/TAB)            // Read-only    // [Completion,History]
2177
    char*               Buf;            // Text buffer                          // Read-write   // [Resize] Can replace pointer / [Completion,History,Always] Only write to pointed data, don't replace the actual pointer!
2178
    int                 BufTextLen;     // Text length (in bytes)               // Read-write   // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Exclude zero-terminator storage. In C land: == strlen(some_text), in C++ land: string.length()
2179
    int                 BufSize;        // Buffer size (in bytes) = capacity+1  // Read-only    // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Include zero-terminator storage. In C land == ARRAYSIZE(my_char_array), in C++ land: string.capacity()+1
2180
    bool                BufDirty;       // Set if you modify Buf/BufTextLen!    // Write        // [Completion,History,Always]
2181
    int                 CursorPos;      //                                      // Read-write   // [Completion,History,Always]
2182
    int                 SelectionStart; //                                      // Read-write   // [Completion,History,Always] == to SelectionEnd when no selection)
2183
    int                 SelectionEnd;   //                                      // Read-write   // [Completion,History,Always]
2184
2185
    // Helper functions for text manipulation.
2186
    // Use those function to benefit from the CallbackResize behaviors. Calling those function reset the selection.
2187
    IMGUI_API ImGuiInputTextCallbackData();
2188
    IMGUI_API void      DeleteChars(int pos, int bytes_count);
2189
    IMGUI_API void      InsertChars(int pos, const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL);
2190
0
    void                SelectAll()             { SelectionStart = 0; SelectionEnd = BufTextLen; }
2191
0
    void                ClearSelection()        { SelectionStart = SelectionEnd = BufTextLen; }
2192
0
    bool                HasSelection() const    { return SelectionStart != SelectionEnd; }
2193
};
2194
2195
// Resizing callback data to apply custom constraint. As enabled by SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(). Callback is called during the next Begin().
2196
// NB: For basic min/max size constraint on each axis you don't need to use the callback! The SetNextWindowSizeConstraints() parameters are enough.
2197
struct ImGuiSizeCallbackData
2198
{
2199
    void*   UserData;       // Read-only.   What user passed to SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(). Generally store an integer or float in here (need reinterpret_cast<>).
2200
    ImVec2  Pos;            // Read-only.   Window position, for reference.
2201
    ImVec2  CurrentSize;    // Read-only.   Current window size.
2202
    ImVec2  DesiredSize;    // Read-write.  Desired size, based on user's mouse position. Write to this field to restrain resizing.
2203
};
2204
2205
// [ALPHA] Rarely used / very advanced uses only. Use with SetNextWindowClass() and DockSpace() functions.
2206
// Important: the content of this class is still highly WIP and likely to change and be refactored
2207
// before we stabilize Docking features. Please be mindful if using this.
2208
// Provide hints:
2209
// - To the platform backend via altered viewport flags (enable/disable OS decoration, OS task bar icons, etc.)
2210
// - To the platform backend for OS level parent/child relationships of viewport.
2211
// - To the docking system for various options and filtering.
2212
struct ImGuiWindowClass
2213
{
2214
    ImGuiID             ClassId;                    // User data. 0 = Default class (unclassed). Windows of different classes cannot be docked with each others.
2215
    ImGuiID             ParentViewportId;           // Hint for the platform backend. -1: use default. 0: request platform backend to not parent the platform. != 0: request platform backend to create a parent<>child relationship between the platform windows. Not conforming backends are free to e.g. parent every viewport to the main viewport or not.
2216
    ImGuiViewportFlags  ViewportFlagsOverrideSet;   // Viewport flags to set when a window of this class owns a viewport. This allows you to enforce OS decoration or task bar icon, override the defaults on a per-window basis.
2217
    ImGuiViewportFlags  ViewportFlagsOverrideClear; // Viewport flags to clear when a window of this class owns a viewport. This allows you to enforce OS decoration or task bar icon, override the defaults on a per-window basis.
2218
    ImGuiTabItemFlags   TabItemFlagsOverrideSet;    // [EXPERIMENTAL] TabItem flags to set when a window of this class gets submitted into a dock node tab bar. May use with ImGuiTabItemFlags_Leading or ImGuiTabItemFlags_Trailing.
2219
    ImGuiDockNodeFlags  DockNodeFlagsOverrideSet;   // [EXPERIMENTAL] Dock node flags to set when a window of this class is hosted by a dock node (it doesn't have to be selected!)
2220
    bool                DockingAlwaysTabBar;        // Set to true to enforce single floating windows of this class always having their own docking node (equivalent of setting the global io.ConfigDockingAlwaysTabBar)
2221
    bool                DockingAllowUnclassed;      // Set to true to allow windows of this class to be docked/merged with an unclassed window. // FIXME-DOCK: Move to DockNodeFlags override?
2222
2223
7
    ImGuiWindowClass() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); ParentViewportId = (ImGuiID)-1; DockingAllowUnclassed = true; }
2224
};
2225

struct ImGuiPayload
2228
{
2229
    // Members
2230
    void*           Data;               // Data (copied and owned by dear imgui)
2231
    int             DataSize;           // Data size
2232

    // [Internal]
2234
    ImGuiID         SourceId;           // Source item id
2235
    ImGuiID         SourceParentId;     // Source parent id (if available)
2236
    int             DataFrameCount;     // Data timestamp
2237
    char            DataType[32 + 1];   // Data type tag (short user-supplied string, 32 characters max)
2238
    bool            Preview;            // Set when AcceptDragDropPayload() was called and mouse has been hovering the target item (nb: handle overlapping drag targets)
2239
    bool            Delivery;           // Set when AcceptDragDropPayload() was called and mouse button is released over the target item.
2240
2241
1
    ImGuiPayload()  { Clear(); }
2242
1
    void Clear()    { SourceId = SourceParentId = 0; Data = NULL; DataSize = 0; memset(DataType, 0, sizeof(DataType)); DataFrameCount = -1; Preview = Delivery = false; }
2243
0
    bool IsDataType(const char* type) const { return DataFrameCount != -1 && strcmp(type, DataType) == 0; }
2244
0
    bool IsPreview() const                  { return Preview; }
2245
0
    bool IsDelivery() const                 { return Delivery; }
2246
};

// Sorting specification for one column of a table (sizeof == 12 bytes)
2249
struct ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs
2250
{
2251

2252

2253
    ImS16                       SortOrder;          // Index within parent ImGuiTableSortSpecs (always stored in order starting from 0, tables sorted on a single criteria will always have a 0 here)
2254
    ImGuiSortDirection          SortDirection : 8;  // ImGuiSortDirection_Ascending or ImGuiSortDirection_Descending (you can use this or SortSign, whichever is more convenient for your sort function)
2255
2256
0
    ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); }

};
2258
2259
// Sorting specifications for a table (often handling sort specs for a single column, occasionally more)
2260
// Obtained by calling TableGetSortSpecs().
2261
// When 'SpecsDirty == true' you can sort your data. It will be true with sorting specs have changed since last call, or the first time.
2262
// Make sure to set 'SpecsDirty = false' after sorting, else you may wastefully sort your data every frame!
2263
struct ImGuiTableSortSpecs
2264
{
2265
    const ImGuiTableColumnSortSpecs* Specs;     // Pointer to sort spec array.
2266
    int                         SpecsCount;     // Sort spec count. Most often 1. May be > 1 when ImGuiTableFlags_SortMulti is enabled. May be == 0 when ImGuiTableFlags_SortTristate is enabled.
2267
    bool                        SpecsDirty;     // Set to true when specs have changed since last time! Use this to sort again, then clear the flag.
2268
2269
0
    ImGuiTableSortSpecs()       { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); }
2270
};

// Helper: Execute a block of code at maximum once a frame. Convenient if you want to quickly create a UI within deep-nested code that runs multiple times every frame.
2285
// Usage: static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame oaf; if (oaf) ImGui::Text("This will be called only once per frame");
2286
struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame
2287
{

0
    ImGuiOnceUponAFrame() { RefFrame = -1; }
2289
    mutable int RefFrame;
2290
0
    operator bool() const { int current_frame = ImGui::GetFrameCount(); if (RefFrame == current_frame) return false; RefFrame = current_frame; return true; }
2291
};

2320

2321
struct ImGuiTextBuffer
2322
{
2323
    ImVector<char>      Buf;
2324
    IMGUI_API static char EmptyString[1];
2325
2326
3
    ImGuiTextBuffer()   { }
2327
0
    inline char         operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(Buf.Data != NULL); return Buf.Data[i]; }
2328
0
    const char*         begin() const           { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.front() : EmptyString; }
2329
0
    const char*         end() const             { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.back() : EmptyString; }   // Buf is zero-terminated, so end() will point on the zero-terminator
2330
0
    int                 size() const            { return Buf.Size ? Buf.Size - 1 : 0; }
2331
0
    bool                empty() const           { return Buf.Size <= 1; }
2332
0
    void                clear()                 { Buf.clear(); }
2333
0
    void                reserve(int capacity)   { Buf.reserve(capacity); }
2334
0
    const char*         c_str() const           { return Buf.Data ? Buf.Data : EmptyString; }
2335
    IMGUI_API void      append(const char* str, const char* str_end = NULL);
2336
    IMGUI_API void      appendf(const char* fmt, ...) IM_FMTARGS(2);

};

2340
// Helper: Key->Value storage
2341
// Typically you don't have to worry about this since a storage is held within each Window.
2342
// We use it to e.g. store collapse state for a tree (Int 0/1)
2343
// This is optimized for efficient lookup (dichotomy into a contiguous buffer) and rare insertion (typically tied to user interactions aka max once a frame)
2344
// You can use it as custom user storage for temporary values. Declare your own storage if, for example:
2345
// - You want to manipulate the open/close state of a particular sub-tree in your interface (tree node uses Int 0/1 to store their state).
2346
// - You want to store custom debug data easily without adding or editing structures in your code (probably not efficient, but convenient)
2347
// Types are NOT stored, so it is up to you to make sure your Key don't collide with different types.
2348
struct ImGuiStorage
2349
{
2350
    // [Internal]
2351
    struct ImGuiStoragePair
2352
    {
2353
        ImGuiID key;
2354
        union { int val_i; float val_f; void* val_p; };
2355
0
        ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, int _val_i)      { key = _key; val_i = _val_i; }
2356
0
        ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, float _val_f)    { key = _key; val_f = _val_f; }
2357
3
        ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, void* _val_p)    { key = _key; val_p = _val_p; }
2358
    };
2359
2360
    ImVector<ImGuiStoragePair>      Data;
2361
2362
    // - Get***() functions find pair, never add/allocate. Pairs are sorted so a query is O(log N)
2363
    // - Set***() functions find pair, insertion on demand if missing.
2364
    // - Sorted insertion is costly, paid once. A typical frame shouldn't need to insert any new pair.
2365
0
    void                Clear() { Data.clear(); }
2366
    IMGUI_API int       GetInt(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0) const;
2367
    IMGUI_API void      SetInt(ImGuiID key, int val);
2368
    IMGUI_API bool      GetBool(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false) const;
2369
    IMGUI_API void      SetBool(ImGuiID key, bool val);
2370
    IMGUI_API float     GetFloat(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f) const;
2371
    IMGUI_API void      SetFloat(ImGuiID key, float val);
2372
    IMGUI_API void*     GetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key) const; // default_val is NULL
2373
    IMGUI_API void      SetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key, void* val);
2374
2375
    // - Get***Ref() functions finds pair, insert on demand if missing, return pointer. Useful if you intend to do Get+Set.
2376
    // - References are only valid until a new value is added to the storage. Calling a Set***() function or a Get***Ref() function invalidates the pointer.
2377
    // - A typical use case where this is convenient for quick hacking (e.g. add storage during a live Edit&Continue session if you can't modify existing struct)
2378
    //      float* pvar = ImGui::GetFloatRef(key); ImGui::SliderFloat("var", pvar, 0, 100.0f); some_var += *pvar;
2379
    IMGUI_API int*      GetIntRef(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0);
2380
    IMGUI_API bool*     GetBoolRef(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false);
2381
    IMGUI_API float*    GetFloatRef(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f);
2382
    IMGUI_API void**    GetVoidPtrRef(ImGuiID key, void* default_val = NULL);
2383
2384
    // Use on your own storage if you know only integer are being stored (open/close all tree nodes)
2385
    IMGUI_API void      SetAllInt(int val);
2386
2387
    // For quicker full rebuild of a storage (instead of an incremental one), you may add all your contents and then sort once.
2388
    IMGUI_API void      BuildSortByKey();
2389
};
2390
2391
// Helper: Manually clip large list of items.
2392
// If you have lots evenly spaced items and you have random access to the list, you can perform coarse
2393
// clipping based on visibility to only submit items that are in view.
2394
// The clipper calculates the range of visible items and advance the cursor to compensate for the non-visible items we have skipped.
2395
// (Dear ImGui already clip items based on their bounds but: it needs to first layout the item to do so, and generally
2396
//  fetching/submitting your own data incurs additional cost. Coarse clipping using ImGuiListClipper allows you to easily
2397
//  scale using lists with tens of thousands of items without a problem)
2398
// Usage:
2399
//   ImGuiListClipper clipper;
2400
//   clipper.Begin(1000);         // We have 1000 elements, evenly spaced.
2401
//   while (clipper.Step())
2402
//       for (int i = clipper.DisplayStart; i < clipper.DisplayEnd; i++)
2403
//           ImGui::Text("line number %d", i);
2404
// Generally what happens is:
2405
// - Clipper lets you process the first element (DisplayStart = 0, DisplayEnd = 1) regardless of it being visible or not.
2406
// - User code submit that one element.
2407
// - Clipper can measure the height of the first element
2408
// - Clipper calculate the actual range of elements to display based on the current clipping rectangle, position the cursor before the first visible element.
2409
// - User code submit visible elements.
2410
// - The clipper also handles various subtleties related to keyboard/gamepad navigation, wrapping etc.
2411
struct ImGuiListClipper
2412
{
2413
    int             DisplayStart;       // First item to display, updated by each call to Step()
2414
    int             DisplayEnd;         // End of items to display (exclusive)
2415
    int             ItemsCount;         // [Internal] Number of items
2416
    float           ItemsHeight;        // [Internal] Height of item after a first step and item submission can calculate it
2417
    float           StartPosY;          // [Internal] Cursor position at the time of Begin() or after table frozen rows are all processed
2418
    void*           TempData;           // [Internal] Internal data
2419
2420
    // items_count: Use INT_MAX if you don't know how many items you have (in which case the cursor won't be advanced in the final step)
2421
    // items_height: Use -1.0f to be calculated automatically on first step. Otherwise pass in the distance between your items, typically GetTextLineHeightWithSpacing() or GetFrameHeightWithSpacing().
2422
    IMGUI_API ImGuiListClipper();
2423
    IMGUI_API ~ImGuiListClipper();
2424
    IMGUI_API void  Begin(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f);
2425
    IMGUI_API void  End();             // Automatically called on the last call of Step() that returns false.
2426
    IMGUI_API bool  Step();            // Call until it returns false. The DisplayStart/DisplayEnd fields will be set and you can process/draw those items.
2427
2428
    // Call ForceDisplayRangeByIndices() before first call to Step() if you need a range of items to be displayed regardless of visibility.
2429
    IMGUI_API void  ForceDisplayRangeByIndices(int item_min, int item_max); // item_max is exclusive e.g. use (42, 42+1) to make item 42 always visible BUT due to alignment/padding of certain items it is likely that an extra item may be included on either end of the display range.
2430
2431
#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
2432
    inline ImGuiListClipper(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f) { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); ItemsCount = -1; Begin(items_count, items_height); } // [removed in 1.79]
2433
#endif
2434
};
2435
2436
// Helpers macros to generate 32-bit encoded colors
2437
// User can declare their own format by #defining the 5 _SHIFT/_MASK macros in their imconfig file.
2438
#ifndef IM_COL32_R_SHIFT
2439
#ifdef IMGUI_USE_BGRA_PACKED_COLOR
2440
#define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT    16
2441
#define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT    8
2442
#define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT    0
2443
#define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT    24
2444
#define IM_COL32_A_MASK     0xFF000000
2445
#else
2446
568k
#define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT    0
2447
568k
#define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT    8
2448
568k
#define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT    16
2449
568k
#define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT    24
2450
18.7M
#define IM_COL32_A_MASK     0xFF000000
2451
#endif
2452
#endif
2453
32.7k
#define IM_COL32(R,G,B,A)    (((ImU32)(A)<<IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(B)<<IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(G)<<IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(R)<<IM_COL32_R_SHIFT))
2454
0
#define IM_COL32_WHITE       IM_COL32(255,255,255,255)  // Opaque white = 0xFFFFFFFF
2455
0
#define IM_COL32_BLACK       IM_COL32(0,0,0,255)        // Opaque black
2456
0
#define IM_COL32_BLACK_TRANS IM_COL32(0,0,0,0)          // Transparent black = 0x00000000
2457
2458
// Helper: ImColor() implicitly converts colors to either ImU32 (packed 4x1 byte) or ImVec4 (4x1 float)
2459
// Prefer using IM_COL32() macros if you want a guaranteed compile-time ImU32 for usage with ImDrawList API.
2460
// **Avoid storing ImColor! Store either u32 of ImVec4. This is not a full-featured color class. MAY OBSOLETE.
2461
// **None of the ImGui API are using ImColor directly but you can use it as a convenience to pass colors in either ImU32 or ImVec4 formats. Explicitly cast to ImU32 or ImVec4 if needed.
2462
struct ImColor
2463
{
2464
    ImVec4          Value;
2465
2466
0
    constexpr ImColor()                                             { }
2467
0
    constexpr ImColor(float r, float g, float b, float a = 1.0f)    : Value(r, g, b, a) { }
2468
0
    constexpr ImColor(const ImVec4& col)                            : Value(col) {}
2469
0
    ImColor(int r, int g, int b, int a = 255)                       { float sc = 1.0f / 255.0f; Value.x = (float)r * sc; Value.y = (float)g * sc; Value.z = (float)b * sc; Value.w = (float)a * sc; }
2470
0
    ImColor(ImU32 rgba)                                             { float sc = 1.0f / 255.0f; Value.x = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_R_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; Value.y = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; Value.z = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; Value.w = (float)((rgba >> IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) & 0xFF) * sc; }
2471
0
    inline operator ImU32() const                                   { return ImGui::ColorConvertFloat4ToU32(Value); }
2472
0
    inline operator ImVec4() const                                  { return Value; }
2473
2474
    // FIXME-OBSOLETE: May need to obsolete/cleanup those helpers.
2475
0
    inline void    SetHSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f){ ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, Value.x, Value.y, Value.z); Value.w = a; }
2476
0
    static ImColor HSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f)   { float r, g, b; ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, r, g, b); return ImColor(r, g, b, a); }
2477
};
2478
2479
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2480
// [SECTION] Drawing API (ImDrawCmd, ImDrawIdx, ImDrawVert, ImDrawChannel, ImDrawListSplitter, ImDrawListFlags, ImDrawList, ImDrawData)
2481
// Hold a series of drawing commands. The user provides a renderer for ImDrawData which essentially contains an array of ImDrawList.
2482
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2483
2484
// The maximum line width to bake anti-aliased textures for. Build atlas with ImFontAtlasFlags_NoBakedLines to disable baking.
2485
#ifndef IM_DRAWLIST_TEX_LINES_WIDTH_MAX
2486
136k
#define IM_DRAWLIST_TEX_LINES_WIDTH_MAX     (63)
2487
#endif
2488
2489
// ImDrawCallback: Draw callbacks for advanced uses [configurable type: override in imconfig.h]
2490
// NB: You most likely do NOT need to use draw callbacks just to create your own widget or customized UI rendering,
2491
// you can poke into the draw list for that! Draw callback may be useful for example to:
2492
//  A) Change your GPU render state,
2493
//  B) render a complex 3D scene inside a UI element without an intermediate texture/render target, etc.
2494
// The expected behavior from your rendering function is 'if (cmd.UserCallback != NULL) { cmd.UserCallback(parent_list, cmd); } else { RenderTriangles() }'
2495
// If you want to override the signature of ImDrawCallback, you can simply use e.g. '#define ImDrawCallback MyDrawCallback' (in imconfig.h) + update rendering backend accordingly.
2496
#ifndef ImDrawCallback
2497
typedef void (*ImDrawCallback)(const ImDrawList* parent_list, const ImDrawCmd* cmd);
2498
#endif
2499
2500
// Special Draw callback value to request renderer backend to reset the graphics/render state.
2501
// The renderer backend needs to handle this special value, otherwise it will crash trying to call a function at this address.
2502
// This is useful for example if you submitted callbacks which you know have altered the render state and you want it to be restored.
2503
// It is not done by default because they are many perfectly useful way of altering render state for imgui contents (e.g. changing shader/blending settings before an Image call).
2504
0
#define ImDrawCallback_ResetRenderState     (ImDrawCallback)(-1)
2505
2506
// Typically, 1 command = 1 GPU draw call (unless command is a callback)
2507
// - VtxOffset: When 'io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled,
2508
//   this fields allow us to render meshes larger than 64K vertices while keeping 16-bit indices.
2509
//   Backends made for <1.71. will typically ignore the VtxOffset fields.
2510
// - The ClipRect/TextureId/VtxOffset fields must be contiguous as we memcmp() them together (this is asserted for).
2511
struct ImDrawCmd
2512
{
2513
    ImVec4          ClipRect;           // 4*4  // Clipping rectangle (x1, y1, x2, y2). Subtract ImDrawData->DisplayPos to get clipping rectangle in "viewport" coordinates
2514
    ImTextureID     TextureId;          // 4-8  // User-provided texture ID. Set by user in ImfontAtlas::SetTexID() for fonts or passed to Image*() functions. Ignore if never using images or multiple fonts atlas.
2515
    unsigned int    VtxOffset;          // 4    // Start offset in vertex buffer. ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: always 0, otherwise may be >0 to support meshes larger than 64K vertices with 16-bit indices.
2516
    unsigned int    IdxOffset;          // 4    // Start offset in index buffer.
2517
    unsigned int    ElemCount;          // 4    // Number of indices (multiple of 3) to be rendered as triangles. Vertices are stored in the callee ImDrawList's vtx_buffer[] array, indices in idx_buffer[].
2518
    ImDrawCallback  UserCallback;       // 4-8  // If != NULL, call the function instead of rendering the vertices. clip_rect and texture_id will be set normally.
2519
    void*           UserCallbackData;   // 4-8  // The draw callback code can access this.
2520
2521
161k
    ImDrawCmd() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); } // Also ensure our padding fields are zeroed
2522
2523
    // Since 1.83: returns ImTextureID associated with this draw call. Warning: DO NOT assume this is always same as 'TextureId' (we will change this function for an upcoming feature)
2524
0
    inline ImTextureID GetTexID() const { return TextureId; }
2525
};
2526
2527
// Vertex layout
2528
#ifndef IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT
2529
struct ImDrawVert
2530
{
2531
    ImVec2  pos;
2532
    ImVec2  uv;
2533
    ImU32   col;
2534
};
2535
#else
2536
// You can override the vertex format layout by defining IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT in imconfig.h
2537
// The code expect ImVec2 pos (8 bytes), ImVec2 uv (8 bytes), ImU32 col (4 bytes), but you can re-order them or add other fields as needed to simplify integration in your engine.
2538
// The type has to be described within the macro (you can either declare the struct or use a typedef). This is because ImVec2/ImU32 are likely not declared at the time you'd want to set your type up.
2539
// NOTE: IMGUI DOESN'T CLEAR THE STRUCTURE AND DOESN'T CALL A CONSTRUCTOR SO ANY CUSTOM FIELD WILL BE UNINITIALIZED. IF YOU ADD EXTRA FIELDS (SUCH AS A 'Z' COORDINATES) YOU WILL NEED TO CLEAR THEM DURING RENDER OR TO IGNORE THEM.
2540
IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT;
2541
#endif
2542
2543
// [Internal] For use by ImDrawList
2544
struct ImDrawCmdHeader
2545
{
2546
    ImVec4          ClipRect;
2547
    ImTextureID     TextureId;
2548
    unsigned int    VtxOffset;
2549
};

// [Internal] For use by ImDrawListSplitter
2552
struct ImDrawChannel
2553
{
2554
    ImVector<ImDrawCmd>         _CmdBuffer;
2555
    ImVector<ImDrawIdx>         _IdxBuffer;
2556
};

2559
// Split/Merge functions are used to split the draw list into different layers which can be drawn into out of order.
2560
// This is used by the Columns/Tables API, so items of each column can be batched together in a same draw call.
2561
struct ImDrawListSplitter
2562
{
2563
    int                         _Current;    // Current channel number (0)
2564
    int                         _Count;      // Number of active channels (1+)
2565
    ImVector<ImDrawChannel>     _Channels;   // Draw channels (not resized down so _Count might be < Channels.Size)
2566
2567
3
    inline ImDrawListSplitter()  { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); }
2568
0
    inline ~ImDrawListSplitter() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
2569
69.2k
    inline void                 Clear() { _Current = 0; _Count = 1; } // Do not clear Channels[] so our allocations are reused next frame
2570
    IMGUI_API void              ClearFreeMemory();
2571
    IMGUI_API void              Split(ImDrawList* draw_list, int count);
2572
    IMGUI_API void              Merge(ImDrawList* draw_list);
2573
    IMGUI_API void              SetCurrentChannel(ImDrawList* draw_list, int channel_idx);
2574
};
2575
2576
// Flags for ImDrawList functions
2577
// (Legacy: bit 0 must always correspond to ImDrawFlags_Closed to be backward compatible with old API using a bool. Bits 1..3 must be unused)
2578
enum ImDrawFlags_
2579
{
2580
    ImDrawFlags_None                        = 0,
2581
    ImDrawFlags_Closed                      = 1 << 0, // PathStroke(), AddPolyline(): specify that shape should be closed (Important: this is always == 1 for legacy reason)
2582
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft         = 1 << 4, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding top-left corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Was 0x01.
2583
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight        = 1 << 5, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding top-right corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Was 0x02.
2584
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft      = 1 << 6, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding bottom-left corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Was 0x04.
2585
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight     = 1 << 7, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): enable rounding bottom-right corner only (when rounding > 0.0f, we default to all corners). Wax 0x08.
2586
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersNone            = 1 << 8, // AddRect(), AddRectFilled(), PathRect(): disable rounding on all corners (when rounding > 0.0f). This is NOT zero, NOT an implicit flag!
2587
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTop             = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight,
2588
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottom          = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight,
2589
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersLeft            = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft,
2590
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersRight           = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight,
2591
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersAll             = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersTopRight | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomLeft | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersBottomRight,
2592
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersDefault_        = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersAll, // Default to ALL corners if none of the _RoundCornersXX flags are specified.
2593
    ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersMask_           = ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersAll | ImDrawFlags_RoundCornersNone,
2594
};
2595
2596
// Flags for ImDrawList instance. Those are set automatically by ImGui:: functions from ImGuiIO settings, and generally not manipulated directly.
2597
// It is however possible to temporarily alter flags between calls to ImDrawList:: functions.
2598
enum ImDrawListFlags_
2599
{
2600
    ImDrawListFlags_None                    = 0,
2601
    ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLines        = 1 << 0,  // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders (*2 the number of triangles for 1.0f wide line or lines thin enough to be drawn using textures, otherwise *3 the number of triangles)
2602
    ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLinesUseTex  = 1 << 1,  // Enable anti-aliased lines/borders using textures when possible. Require backend to render with bilinear filtering (NOT point/nearest filtering).
2603
    ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedFill         = 1 << 2,  // Enable anti-aliased edge around filled shapes (rounded rectangles, circles).
2604
    ImDrawListFlags_AllowVtxOffset          = 1 << 3,  // Can emit 'VtxOffset > 0' to allow large meshes. Set when 'ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled.
2605
};
2606
2607
// Draw command list
2608
// This is the low-level list of polygons that ImGui:: functions are filling. At the end of the frame,
2609
// all command lists are passed to your ImGuiIO::RenderDrawListFn function for rendering.
2610
// Each dear imgui window contains its own ImDrawList. You can use ImGui::GetWindowDrawList() to
2611
// access the current window draw list and draw custom primitives.
2612
// You can interleave normal ImGui:: calls and adding primitives to the current draw list.
2613
// In single viewport mode, top-left is == GetMainViewport()->Pos (generally 0,0), bottom-right is == GetMainViewport()->Pos+Size (generally io.DisplaySize).
2614
// You are totally free to apply whatever transformation matrix to want to the data (depending on the use of the transformation you may want to apply it to ClipRect as well!)
2615
// Important: Primitives are always added to the list and not culled (culling is done at higher-level by ImGui:: functions), if you use this API a lot consider coarse culling your drawn objects.
2616
struct ImDrawList
2617
{
2618
    // This is what you have to render
2619
    ImVector<ImDrawCmd>     CmdBuffer;          // Draw commands. Typically 1 command = 1 GPU draw call, unless the command is a callback.
2620
    ImVector<ImDrawIdx>     IdxBuffer;          // Index buffer. Each command consume ImDrawCmd::ElemCount of those
2621
    ImVector<ImDrawVert>    VtxBuffer;          // Vertex buffer.
2622
    ImDrawListFlags         Flags;              // Flags, you may poke into these to adjust anti-aliasing settings per-primitive.
2623
2624
    // [Internal, used while building lists]
2625
    unsigned int            _VtxCurrentIdx;     // [Internal] generally == VtxBuffer.Size unless we are past 64K vertices, in which case this gets reset to 0.
2626
    ImDrawListSharedData*   _Data;              // Pointer to shared draw data (you can use ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() to get the one from current ImGui context)
2627
    const char*             _OwnerName;         // Pointer to owner window's name for debugging
2628
    ImDrawVert*             _VtxWritePtr;       // [Internal] point within VtxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
2629
    ImDrawIdx*              _IdxWritePtr;       // [Internal] point within IdxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
2630
    ImVector<ImVec4>        _ClipRectStack;     // [Internal]
2631
    ImVector<ImTextureID>   _TextureIdStack;    // [Internal]
2632
    ImVector<ImVec2>        _Path;              // [Internal] current path building
2633
    ImDrawCmdHeader         _CmdHeader;         // [Internal] template of active commands. Fields should match those of CmdBuffer.back().
2634
    ImDrawListSplitter      _Splitter;          // [Internal] for channels api (note: prefer using your own persistent instance of ImDrawListSplitter!)
2635
    float                   _FringeScale;       // [Internal] anti-alias fringe is scaled by this value, this helps to keep things sharp while zooming at vertex buffer content
2636
2637
    // If you want to create ImDrawList instances, pass them ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() or create and use your own ImDrawListSharedData (so you can use ImDrawList without ImGui)
2638
3
    ImDrawList(ImDrawListSharedData* shared_data) { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); _Data = shared_data; }
2639
2640
0
    ~ImDrawList() { _ClearFreeMemory(); }
2641
    IMGUI_API void  PushClipRect(const ImVec2& clip_rect_min, const ImVec2& clip_rect_max, bool intersect_with_current_clip_rect = false);  // Render-level scissoring. This is passed down to your render function but not used for CPU-side coarse clipping. Prefer using higher-level ImGui::PushClipRect() to affect logic (hit-testing and widget culling)
2642
    IMGUI_API void  PushClipRectFullScreen();
2643
    IMGUI_API void  PopClipRect();
2644
    IMGUI_API void  PushTextureID(ImTextureID texture_id);
2645
    IMGUI_API void  PopTextureID();
2646
0
    inline ImVec2   GetClipRectMin() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.x, cr.y); }
2647
0
    inline ImVec2   GetClipRectMax() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.z, cr.w); }
2648
2649
    // Primitives
2650
    // - Filled shapes must always use clockwise winding order. The anti-aliasing fringe depends on it. Counter-clockwise shapes will have "inward" anti-aliasing.
2651
    // - For rectangular primitives, "p_min" and "p_max" represent the upper-left and lower-right corners.
2652
    // - For circle primitives, use "num_segments == 0" to automatically calculate tessellation (preferred).
2653
    //   In older versions (until Dear ImGui 1.77) the AddCircle functions defaulted to num_segments == 12.
2654
    //   In future versions we will use textures to provide cheaper and higher-quality circles.
2655
    //   Use AddNgon() and AddNgonFilled() functions if you need to guarantee a specific number of sides.
2656
    IMGUI_API void  AddLine(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
2657
    IMGUI_API void  AddRect(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawFlags flags = 0, float thickness = 1.0f);   // a: upper-left, b: lower-right (== upper-left + size)
2658
    IMGUI_API void  AddRectFilled(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawFlags flags = 0);                     // a: upper-left, b: lower-right (== upper-left + size)
2659
    IMGUI_API void  AddRectFilledMultiColor(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col_upr_left, ImU32 col_upr_right, ImU32 col_bot_right, ImU32 col_bot_left);
2660
    IMGUI_API void  AddQuad(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
2661
    IMGUI_API void  AddQuadFilled(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col);
2662
    IMGUI_API void  AddTriangle(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
2663
    IMGUI_API void  AddTriangleFilled(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col);
2664
    IMGUI_API void  AddCircle(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments = 0, float thickness = 1.0f);
2665
    IMGUI_API void  AddCircleFilled(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments = 0);
2666
    IMGUI_API void  AddNgon(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments, float thickness = 1.0f);
2667
    IMGUI_API void  AddNgonFilled(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments);
2668
    IMGUI_API void  AddText(const ImVec2& pos, ImU32 col, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL);
2669
    IMGUI_API void  AddText(const ImFont* font, float font_size, const ImVec2& pos, ImU32 col, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL, float wrap_width = 0.0f, const ImVec4* cpu_fine_clip_rect = NULL);
2670
    IMGUI_API void  AddPolyline(const ImVec2* points, int num_points, ImU32 col, ImDrawFlags flags, float thickness);
2671
    IMGUI_API void  AddConvexPolyFilled(const ImVec2* points, int num_points, ImU32 col);
2672
    IMGUI_API void  AddBezierCubic(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col, float thickness, int num_segments = 0); // Cubic Bezier (4 control points)
2673
    IMGUI_API void  AddBezierQuadratic(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col, float thickness, int num_segments = 0);               // Quadratic Bezier (3 control points)
2674
2675
    // Image primitives
2676
    // - Read FAQ to understand what ImTextureID is.
2677
    // - "p_min" and "p_max" represent the upper-left and lower-right corners of the rectangle.
2678
    // - "uv_min" and "uv_max" represent the normalized texture coordinates to use for those corners. Using (0,0)->(1,1) texture coordinates will generally display the entire texture.
2679
    IMGUI_API void  AddImage(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, const ImVec2& uv_min = ImVec2(0, 0), const ImVec2& uv_max = ImVec2(1, 1), ImU32 col = IM_COL32_WHITE);
2680
    IMGUI_API void  AddImageQuad(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, const ImVec2& uv1 = ImVec2(0, 0), const ImVec2& uv2 = ImVec2(1, 0), const ImVec2& uv3 = ImVec2(1, 1), const ImVec2& uv4 = ImVec2(0, 1), ImU32 col = IM_COL32_WHITE);
2681
    IMGUI_API void  AddImageRounded(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, const ImVec2& uv_min, const ImVec2& uv_max, ImU32 col, float rounding, ImDrawFlags flags = 0);
2682
2683
    // Stateful path API, add points then finish with PathFillConvex() or PathStroke()
2684
    // - Filled shapes must always use clockwise winding order. The anti-aliasing fringe depends on it. Counter-clockwise shapes will have "inward" anti-aliasing.
2685
0
    inline    void  PathClear()                                                 { _Path.Size = 0; }
2686
665k
    inline    void  PathLineTo(const ImVec2& pos)                               { _Path.push_back(pos); }
2687
0
    inline    void  PathLineToMergeDuplicate(const ImVec2& pos)                 { if (_Path.Size == 0 || memcmp(&_Path.Data[_Path.Size - 1], &pos, 8) != 0) _Path.push_back(pos); }
2688
114k
    inline    void  PathFillConvex(ImU32 col)                                   { AddConvexPolyFilled(_Path.Data, _Path.Size, col); _Path.Size = 0; }
2689
136k
    inline    void  PathStroke(ImU32 col, ImDrawFlags flags = 0, float thickness = 1.0f) { AddPolyline(_Path.Data, _Path.Size, col, flags, thickness); _Path.Size = 0; }
2690
    IMGUI_API void  PathArcTo(const ImVec2& center, float radius, float a_min, float a_max, int num_segments = 0);
2691
    IMGUI_API void  PathArcToFast(const ImVec2& center, float radius, int a_min_of_12, int a_max_of_12);                // Use precomputed angles for a 12 steps circle
2692
    IMGUI_API void  PathBezierCubicCurveTo(const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, int num_segments = 0); // Cubic Bezier (4 control points)
2693
    IMGUI_API void  PathBezierQuadraticCurveTo(const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, int num_segments = 0);               // Quadratic Bezier (3 control points)
2694
    IMGUI_API void  PathRect(const ImVec2& rect_min, const ImVec2& rect_max, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawFlags flags = 0);
2695
2696
    // Advanced
2697
    IMGUI_API void  AddCallback(ImDrawCallback callback, void* callback_data);  // Your rendering function must check for 'UserCallback' in ImDrawCmd and call the function instead of rendering triangles.
2698
    IMGUI_API void  AddDrawCmd();                                               // This is useful if you need to forcefully create a new draw call (to allow for dependent rendering / blending). Otherwise primitives are merged into the same draw-call as much as possible
2699
    IMGUI_API ImDrawList* CloneOutput() const;                                  // Create a clone of the CmdBuffer/IdxBuffer/VtxBuffer.
2700
2701
    // Advanced: Channels
2702
    // - Use to split render into layers. By switching channels to can render out-of-order (e.g. submit FG primitives before BG primitives)
2703
    // - Use to minimize draw calls (e.g. if going back-and-forth between multiple clipping rectangles, prefer to append into separate channels then merge at the end)
2704
    // - FIXME-OBSOLETE: This API shouldn't have been in ImDrawList in the first place!
2705
    //   Prefer using your own persistent instance of ImDrawListSplitter as you can stack them.
2706
    //   Using the ImDrawList::ChannelsXXXX you cannot stack a split over another.
2707
0
    inline void     ChannelsSplit(int count)    { _Splitter.Split(this, count); }
2708
0
    inline void     ChannelsMerge()             { _Splitter.Merge(this); }
2709
0
    inline void     ChannelsSetCurrent(int n)   { _Splitter.SetCurrentChannel(this, n); }
2710
2711
    // Advanced: Primitives allocations
2712
    // - We render triangles (three vertices)
2713
    // - All primitives needs to be reserved via PrimReserve() beforehand.
2714
    IMGUI_API void  PrimReserve(int idx_count, int vtx_count);
2715
    IMGUI_API void  PrimUnreserve(int idx_count, int vtx_count);
2716
    IMGUI_API void  PrimRect(const ImVec2& a, const ImVec2& b, ImU32 col);      // Axis aligned rectangle (composed of two triangles)
2717
    IMGUI_API void  PrimRectUV(const ImVec2& a, const ImVec2& b, const ImVec2& uv_a, const ImVec2& uv_b, ImU32 col);
2718
    IMGUI_API void  PrimQuadUV(const ImVec2& a, const ImVec2& b, const ImVec2& c, const ImVec2& d, const ImVec2& uv_a, const ImVec2& uv_b, const ImVec2& uv_c, const ImVec2& uv_d, ImU32 col);
2719
0
    inline    void  PrimWriteVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col)    { _VtxWritePtr->pos = pos; _VtxWritePtr->uv = uv; _VtxWritePtr->col = col; _VtxWritePtr++; _VtxCurrentIdx++; }
2720
0
    inline    void  PrimWriteIdx(ImDrawIdx idx)                                     { *_IdxWritePtr = idx; _IdxWritePtr++; }
2721
0
    inline    void  PrimVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col)         { PrimWriteIdx((ImDrawIdx)_VtxCurrentIdx); PrimWriteVtx(pos, uv, col); } // Write vertex with unique index
2722

#ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
2724
    inline    void  AddBezierCurve(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col, float thickness, int num_segments = 0) { AddBezierCubic(p1, p2, p3, p4, col, thickness, num_segments); } // OBSOLETED in 1.80 (Jan 2021)
